subject: Law
title: The International Criminal Court
description: A micro-lesson that makes The International Criminal Court usable.

hook.text: A warlord orders mass killings. His own country won't prosecute. The ICC in The Hague steps in.

buildup.text: The ICC prosecutes individuals for genocide, crimes against humanity, war crimes, and aggression.

discovery.text: It's a court of last resort: it acts only when national courts are unwilling or unable to prosecute.

twist.text: The US, China, and Russia haven't joined the ICC. They argue it threatens sovereignty.

climax.text: Despite limitations, the ICC has secured convictions and put dictators on notice that impunity has limits.

punchline.text: The ICC can't reach everyone. But its existence changes the calculus.

quiz.question: What crimes does the ICC prosecute?
options: Genocide, crimes against humanity, war crimes, aggression
